And whereas the events and decisions of the past year have made the business of our school board, more complicated and consequential for the health of our students and staff into their academic, social and emotional well being. And whereas during this highly volatile Tom the board's connection to students, staff and families became even stronger as the number of opinions and insight offered to the board through emails and messages multiplied as much as 100 fold. as the number of participants at board meetings increased to thousands, as public comment was made more accessible, significantly increasing the number of speakers able to interact with board members, and whereas the transition from in-person to virtual meetings continues to present unplanned management duties, the fulfillment of which are crucial to the effective and responsive functioning of the board, And whereas during this period of time, one constant has been Ms. Jennifer Johnston, who this year was appointed for the 20th consecutive year to serve as a clerk of the board. And whereas Ms. Johnston has performed the new requirements presented by the pandemic while executing the board's priority to expand community engagement, and while also fulfilling her already considerable legal duties as board clerk. And whereas each year, Virginia School Board Association designates one week in February to build awareness of the role board clerks play in assisting school board members, superintendents, and our local schools. And whereas the association reminds us of how especially important this constant awareness is this year when Mrs. Johnston has been so instrumental to our success as we have managed through the barrage of changes resulting from the pandemic. Now therefore be it resolved that the Albemarle County School Board publicly expresses its deepest appreciation to Ms. Jennifer Johnston for her exceptional service and support of our work and therefore of the thousands of student and staff members we serve. And we call upon all constituents to join with us in recognizing Ms. Johnston's invaluable contributions to public education in Albemarle County and to join us in thanking her for two decades of outstanding service as the clerk of the Albemarle County School Board. Thank you.

ellenosborne.monologue: Yes, thank you. So we have a resolution. I'm going to read it now. It's in regard to the Child Nutrition Services. Whereas on Friday, March 13, Virginia Governor Ralph Northam ordered the closing of all schools in the Commonwealth for a period of two weeks to protect against the spread of the coronavirus. And whereas this action to protect public health through the closure of schools meant that students who participated in the federal government's free and reduced lunch program lost their access to the nutritious meals provided each day at school and Whereas in Albemarle County Public Schools, thousands of students were negatively impacted by this loss of access. And whereas among the school division's four values is its young people, specifically their academic and personal development, their health and well-being, And whereas in response to the closure of schools, the division's child nutrition department immediately began to plan to meet the needs of all children for healthy breakfast and lunches on a daily basis. And whereas within one business day of the governor's closure announcement, Child Nutrition Team members, under the guidance of Director Christina Pitzenberger, had organized a food distribution program. And whereas the program began with six school sites throughout the county, serving more than 1,000 meals a day to students and their siblings 18 years of old and younger. And whereas on March 23rd, The governor extended the closure of all K-12 schools in the Commonwealth through the end of the current academic year, and whereas the Child Nutrition Office continued to monitor the need among its students and all communities across the county for healthy meals and to work with the Department of Transportation in setting up additional food distribution sites, And whereas, as the result of this ongoing planning and teamwork, the office now distributes breakfast and lunches to students in 21 locations at schools and communities. And whereas, since March 17th, the Child Nutrition Office has provided more than 30,000 meals to students from all schools and locations in the county, and is continuing to evaluate the needs to further expand this service. Now therefore be it resolved that the Albemarle County School Board expresses its deep appreciation to Ms. Pitsenberger and her highly dedicated and skilled team for their invaluable support in meeting the nutritional and health needs of thousands of Albemarle County public school students and their siblings, and for doing so through such an expeditious and increasingly inclusive plan. And be it further resolved, the school board also salutes the contributions of the transportation department, its director James Foley, and his team for enabling the food distribution program to bring its services directly to the neighborhoods where students reside, thereby expanding participation in this vitally beneficial program. Thank you.

Immediately after the governor's order, our district sprang into action to ensure that these students continued to receive the nutrition they needed. judyle.monologue: So I respect everybody's arguments here. I feel like I really respect our board and the difficulty. I know that we all have been wrestling with this a lot. I don't know if there's a waking moment that I'm not thinking about it, to be honest with you. And I respect all that, and I support a stage one opening. I don't feel like there's any reason to believe we're any safer today than we were when we went into shutdown. We're actually regularly seeing much higher numbers of new cases in our health district than we have at any point during this pandemic, especially since July 4th, and that hasn't abated. The data that Rosalyn presented also makes me feel like we're not ready to have students in our schools. Now, I appreciate the thoughtfulness that went into the stages, because I do think that that's a great way to bring students in. But right now, I don't think that we're in. We're ready to be in stage two. I also don't think that we have any reason to believe it's going to get any better in our health district. The cohort that we have with the second highest number of cases is the 20 to 29-year-old age group. And we're going to get a lot more when UVA opens. And so that's just with UVA closed. And then we're going to get a lot more of them when it opens. And we have many community members who work there. It's not just the students who are affected by that. So I'm not given to believe that there's going to be less risk than there was when we shut down. There are also, I'm still very troubled by a lot of unknowns about this disease. And all these things are not things that we, you know, are in control of. And I'm not, I'm not blaming anyone for them. I'm not saying like we had a bad plan. I'm just saying we have a good plan with different stages. And I don't think we're ready for stage two. There are a lot of unknowns about the disease. There just was a study, like someone sent me a one o'clock today about how kids carry a higher load of the virus. That's in the New York Times today from like 12 p.m. So, but we do also know that students 10 and up pass the virus along just as quickly as adults do, which is very, You know, we don't, we still don't know the long-term effects and the evidence that is mounting is not great on that. Um, I just think that if we have misgivings about bringing staff and students into the building, then we have misgivings about bringing staff and students from those communities that are more likely to experience worse outcomes from COVID. It weighs on me heavily. how we can serve those communities. I mean like, and again, I know that we all have struggled with this, but I can't vote to bring them in yet. I don't see our community with the lack of testing, with the slow testing, you know, people I know who have been exposed to it and have had no contact tracing. And again, like I'm not, I'm not here to blame anyone or cast aspersions. I'm just saying this is the reality that we're looking at. And the reality also includes great health disparities. And so for me, I don't feel comfortable bringing in people from those communities that have those, that suffer from those great health disparities. I feel like our division, like every single division across the United States for the next month has an enormous task, whichever way we go today. Our division has an enormous task of how to educate and serve all of our populations. And for me, when there are going to be quarantines or when there, and we know there are going to be, I mean, we don't have any reason to believe that there aren't. I think we will wish that we had concentrated on serving those populations now for the next month of figuring out how we do serve them than having to face those situations quickly. I think we're creative, I think we're innovative, and I think we can solve those problems. So that's why I will be supporting SH1.

judyle.monologue: Thank you, Chair Page. Whereas since 1972 National School Nurse Day has served to strengthen the understanding of how school nurses have contributed to the academic, social, and emotional development of students, and whereas this year during the most severe pandemic to occur in school communities in 100 years, school nurses have eagerly been frontline protectors of the public health, overseeing health strategies and practices that make school safe places for children, and whereas in gratitude for this service, National School Nurse Day and National School Nurses Week have been expanded to incorporate celebrations, the entire month of May. And whereas in Albemarle County Public Schools in recent years, visits by students and staff to school clinics have exceeded 180,000 or more than 140 visits each hour of every school day. And whereas in a given year, our school nurses record more than 14,000 treatments of students with chronic conditions. And this year, 17 of our school nurses are members of the emergency medical core and have administered COVID-19 vaccines to employees. And whereas school nurses often are the first and on occasion, the primary healthcare provider for families. And whereas the instant actions of school nurses in emergencies have saved lives, prevented more serious illness and injury, and contain the spread of infectious diseases in our schools, and whereas school nurses are invaluable connectors of the school community, families, and health care providers in promoting wellness and access to health care when a child's cognitive development is at its peak. Now, therefore, be it resolved that the Albemarle County School Board does hereby express and call upon all members of the school division and residents of the county to express deepest appreciation to all of our school nurses for their extraordinary and selfless devotion to public health and safety every year, and especially this year, and further resolve that a framed copy of this resolution be provided to every school nurse in the division this May 13th, 2021.

judyle.monologue: I have a couple questions about virtual learning. First, I want to say I do appreciate all of the work and planning that's gone into this. I know that we're not dealing with unlimited resources and we have to make a lot of really difficult decisions to educate 14,000 students. So I really appreciate all the work that staff has done and definitely the people on the ground who are doing every day. So I really appreciate that. I just have a concern about the equity between the virtual learning and the hybrid learning. Also because we know nationally and locally that more of our black and brown families are choosing that. So I just want to make sure that we have some assurances. It will be important to me that we have some assurances that that is robust for my decision making. Firstly, I have a question about intervention services. And I think a way for me to be able to get my head around this is to know how many students will lose intervention services in stage four as it is now. And I know that you don't have those numbers ready, but that's something that I would like to know next week. Also, I would like to know how instructional hours for the hybrid learners will compare with the instructional hours of the virtual learners in K-3, or pre-K-3, I guess, for the four-day-a-week students. I assume that the 4-5, 4-12, I guess, would be the same. But I just would like to know the difference, if there is any difference between the instructional time for those youngest learners. And then I also would like to know how if or how meal services will be affected. For the students who are at home. And then on a different note, I don't know if this is something that Ross considers or we consider how this works. But I wonder if we should be looking at updated mask guidance, given that the new variant is likely coming or here. I know that we've all read a lot in the news about how the single cloth masks are just not as effective now against that. So that's just something I guess I'll throw out there.

judyle.monologue: Thank you, Chair Page. This resolution of the Board of Education of Albemarle County Virginia School Board adopting order number 21-3 of the Director of Emergency Management for the County of Albemarle, Virginia. Whereas the school board recognizes that Albemarle County and the rest of the state of Virginia and the United States are in the midst of a worldwide COVID-19 pandemic that has resulted in more than 600,000 deaths in the United States. And whereas the school board has responded to the challenges brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic, providing students and staff members with the technology and resources necessary to ensure the efficient delivery of instruction virtually and in person. And whereas the school board has a substantial public interest in protecting the health and safety of its students, staff and community, and ensuring that the school division can provide staff and students with a safe and effective educational environment that supports student achievement. And whereas school division staff at all levels are essential to the day-to-day operations of the school division and are responsible for the thorough and efficient education of all students and their social and emotional well-being. And whereas a surge of COVID-19 cases has recently occurred, largely resulting from the Delta variant, also known as B.1.617.2, a highly transmissible virus that impacts individuals regardless of age, And whereas over 90% of COVID-19 infections are currently occurring in individuals who have not been vaccinated against COVID-19. And whereas the overwhelming scientific evidence has established that the vaccines authorized by the FDA for emergency use are safe and effective. and recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for all individuals except children under 12 years of age and certain others, and whereas the school board has the responsibility to prevent the outbreak and spread of COVID-19 infections in its schools and other facilities, and whereas the Director of Emergency Management for the County of Albemarle, Virginia has issued Order Number 21-3 pursuant to Virginia Code 44-146.21c, mandating vaccines, vaccinations, or periodic testing for COVID-19 for the employees of the County of Albemarle. Now, therefore, be it resolved that the school board finds that there exists a public health emergency that requires action to safeguard students and staff against the risks of infection, illness, hospitalization, and death from COVID-19. The school board adopts order number 21 dash three and will work in partnership with the county of Albemarle in the implementation of this order to control the spread of coven 19 in the school division and community. The administration of the school division is directed to develop procedures for the implementation of this resolution that are based upon order number 21-2 as modified to reflect the specific operations of the school division and school board policies, regulations, and code of conduct, and otherwise take all other actions necessary to carry out this mandate. The school board hereby delegates to the superintendent the authority to implement and modify vaccination and testing procedures based on changing conditions and to maintain conformance with the requirements of the CDC, Virginia Department of Health, Blue Ridge Health District, and other applicable health authorities.

One of its purposes was to join in commemorating and encouraging the study, observance, and celebration of the vital role women play in American history. This first day has been awesome. It's been a long time since I've had so many kids in my classroom so I'm just super excited to see them. jonnoalcaro.monologue: Our spotlight on education is a two-part spotlight tonight. So I'm gonna do two different introductions. It's my honor to first introduce two of our students and one of our learning coaches for their extraordinary personal achievements this year. Our students are champions. having earned this distinction last month at our division's annual Spelling Bee. This year, there were two separate competitions, one for our elementary school students and one for our middle schoolers. Lila Theed, a Mountain View fifth grader, finished first among the Spelling Bee winners from all of our elementary schools. And Henry Matthews from Henley placed first among all of our middle school winners. Both Lila and Henry will be competing in the Regional Spelling Bee, the next leg to the National Spelling Bee, which takes place this Saturday morning, beginning at 930 at Albemarle High School. We will also be represented by the second and third place finishers at each level. They include Claire Meng from Hollymead, Madeline Rasmussen from Red Hill, Catriona Shuev from Burling and Seven Gray from Lakeside. Also with us this evening are Katrina Sims and Kim Gibson, two of our lead coaches who serve as coordinators for this year's Bee. Please join me in thanking them and in congratulating Lila and Henry and all who participated in this year's program. I'd like to ask Katrina to formally introduce us to our two champions this evening. Ms. Sims.

jonnoalcaro.monologue: Thank you, Ms. Simmons. The second category is Equity in Education Month. The Virginia School Board Association tells us on their website that when inequity in education persists, there is a cost to all involved, including missed opportunities for economic development, greater dependence on government supports, and fewer Virginians ready to serve and lead. If every student is to fulfill their highest potential, and if the future of our communities is to be both personally rewarding and prosperous, the contributions of our public schools is vital. It is this truth that led the State Board Association to designate March as Equity in Education Month. Tonight we have with us Mary Morales, who is a Spanish teacher in Mountain View's immersion program, serves on the front line of our efforts to institutionalize classroom equity. Mary's story is an unusual one among teachers who have entered our culturally responsive teaching program. She has been a teacher for more than 30 years and more than 20 of those years have been here in our division. Her experience illustrates how this program is changing outcomes for students and for teachers by closing opportunity and achievement gaps. Ms. Morales, I'm hoping that you will bring to life for us tonight some of your insight as to how words about equity translate into better lives for students. Welcome.

First of all, I want to start with a big picture. You know, we put the mask mandate in place last year as part of our strategy for creating safe and healthy environments in which students could return to school. And I believe it has been highly successful.  Moving forward, there's several factors that would influence my decision. Number one would be the data. As it stands right now, there is still quite significant transmission of COVID-19 within our county. The positivity rate remains high. I look at it on a regular basis, and while there have been some drops recently, I think it's premature to say that this is a trend. Secondly, I'm concerned about equity. Now, we've got certain subsets of kids who don't have access to vaccines, or they're not vaccinated because of medical conditions, because their age group isn't eligible yet, or any other reasons. They're still vulnerable. I am deeply concerned about this issue. My first consideration is ensuring that we maintain a safe and healthy environment for all students and staff in our district. If we decide to lift the mask mandate at school, which I don't take lightly, it's important that it's based upon sound data and analysis of health metrics.  I need to know that both our local hospitalization rates and infection numbers within our community have consistently decreased over an agreed-upon period of time. To support such action, we'd need strong evidence that we are moving towards herd immunity and significantly reduced transmission levels. Another crucial aspect I would consider is how our most vulnerable populations will be impacted – students with pre-existing conditions, those who may not yet be eligible for vaccination, or immunocompromised individuals that might still attend our institutions. Moreover, I believe we must consult closely with local health experts, including medical professionals from our area hospitals. These voices provide invaluable insights into emerging trends and offer expert guidance as we navigate these challenges together. Involving them in the decision-making process is essential for evaluating risk and balancing competing priorities effectively. I also want to hear directly from families who entrust their children to us daily. We need to consider different perspectives, concerns, and opinions

If the mitigation plan is going to change, we definitely would like community input and feedback from staff, teachers, parents, and students. It can't just be us making the decision. And I just want to read one statement that I think is highly important. Tomorrow, June 19, is the oldest national celebration of the ending of slavery in the United States. On that day in 1865, A general order was read to the people of the last slave-holding state in the Union in Texas, which said in part, all slaves are now free. The order proclaimed that this action involved the absolute equality of rights between former slaves and their owners. History has sadly not agreed. Over the past 155 years, slavery's disgraceful legacy separated those rights, consistently destroying lives and families and causing incalculable damage to our nation. It is still doing those awful things today. Public schools were not established for such purposes. They were established to be the place where all children would receive equal opportunities to be safe and cared for and to learn and develop at their highest potential. We are not yet such a place. Earlier this week, Governor Northam said, slavery is not just the history of our black communities, this is everyone's shared history. Our anti-racism policy promises, quote, we are committed to establishing and sustaining an equitable community that achieves the school division's equity mission to end the predictive value of race and ensure the success of each individual student and staff member. To appropriately embrace this unity of purpose, It is imperative that our school division join the state and our country, and our county, rather, in designating June 19, Juneteenth, as a time of personal reflection and renewed commitment to racial justice and equality for all. A day that stands in tall fulfillment of the four values of our school division, to serve all of our students all of the time, to partner with members of our community, to respect all, and to achieve excellence in our relationships with all. It is appropriate to celebrate that which is the true place of public education in our communities and in our nation. And so I call upon my colleagues on the board to approve effective immediately that every June 19 will be a day of honor. a day of personal reflection and renewed commitment to equal opportunity and justice for all, and be set aside as a paid holiday for all school division employees. I move that we approve the statement, placing the Juneteenth statement, placing our county in line with county and state guidelines as outlined by Governor Northam.

jonnoalcaro.monologue: Sadly, it wasn't until 45 years ago that the United States formally designated Black History Month. The first celebration already had taken place, fittingly enough, at an educational institution, which was Kent State University, six years prior. Today, the influence of Black History Month enriches the curricula of schools, colleges, and universities throughout our nation, and it should lift the consciousness of all. Its theme this year is Black Family Representation, Identity, and Diversity, exploring in part the strength of Black families across the United States. We don't have to look very far to find a deep personal appreciation and insight why its theme for 2021 so resonates and is so vital to our own school community. In fact, we need look no further than Monticello High School. That's where Autumn King is a sophomore. For many years, Autumn was intrigued by an old family photo in her grandmother's house. It was of a young lady born in the latter half of the 19th century. Autumn often studied the picture, which was of a great, great, great grandmother. a photo that immediately dominated her attention every time she entered the room where it was displayed. Autumn is an outstanding young woman who finds inspiration and guidance from the story of others in life and in art, just as she does every time she becomes reacquainted with that photo and its compelling image. On the eve of Black History Month this year, with its focus on the strength of the Black family, Autumn's grandmother bestowed her with a very special gift. The photo, which has been passed down in the family for more than a century, now has been given to Autumn with the simple explanation, because I know its care will be in good hands. Autumn has written about her great, great, great grandmother, not as a class assignment, but in response to an ancestor who has reached across several generations to speak to her. I'd like to ask Autumn to share her poem with us this evening. And Autumn, we are so glad that you're here with us.

You might remember that in Arlington

Well, you know, I believe that it's very significant because it gives us an opportunity, one, to recognize and reflect on all the rich history and culture that black Americans have contributed to this country. And I think also it gives us an opportunity, two, to look at and address some of the persistent barriers to achieving real equality.  In my own life, you know, having been a student here in the 1970s and coming back as a teacher, and now being a parent in this district, I've seen change happen over time. But unfortunately, many of those challenges that existed when I was a student still exist today for students of color, and especially for African-American students. So I think about the experience of going through high school myself without really seeing a whole lot of teachers or leaders who looked like me. You know, my parents did tell stories to me about segregation and redlining and other things that affected their lives and opportunities. So this month offers us, really, an opportunity to learn from the past, but to not dwell there. As for our community, I truly believe we need to work together towards understanding our past, which shapes who we are today, and also helps us build a more inclusive future. One

grahampaige.monologue: County School Board to order. For our moment of silence, we'd like to have a special remembrance of one of our teachers who passed recently. Powerful ideas sometimes are described as throwing a rock in a river and watching it generate huge ripples that keep getting larger until they encompass a large area. This analogy can fit people as well as ideas. And so it was with Pete Fittner. To give you a sense of the length of his service, he was hired by Joe Vining to teach at Brownsville right out of ed school. In those days, Brownsville had 180 students. Pete also supported math students at Aetna Hurt and Woodbrook, and taught at Burleigh, where he received our community's highest award for teaching, the Golden Apple. His principal, Cassandra Blount, called him a trifecta as a teacher. She described his three superpowers as always building confidence in his students, treating students in a way that makes them want to reach their highest expectations, and he was so skilled in his methods that he could easily adapt to any student's need. He was known at Burleigh as King of the Dungeon, referring to the sixth grade's location on the basement level floor of the school. When you help kids begin to find their place in the world, Pete once said, you begin to find yourself too. Once you embrace who you are, the more you can give to help the students. If you are doing it right, the kids help you through the day. They help you as much as you help them. I want my students to fight for themselves and what they believe in was one of Pete's favorite thoughts. I tell them fight for you and fight for what you want. No matter what happens, you have to keep moving forward. You have to keep fighting. Pete's wife, Nancy, who teaches at Brownsville, said he kept doing that right up until this week. And Pete passed yesterday afternoon. Our condolences and our gratitude go out to the Fittner family. And the next time we see a ripple in that water, we will think of Pete and all the lives that he lifted up. We will now have a moment of silence. This meeting being conducted electronically, we have to read this into our minutes for each meeting. The minutes of this meeting should reflect that this meeting is being held electronically, pursuant to Virginia state law and Albemarle County ordinance, because the COVID-19 pandemic makes it impracticable and unsafe to assemble a quorum physically in a single location. grahampaige.monologue: And I'm Graham Page, Samuel Miller district. a brief intro for our meeting this afternoon. Since March of 2020, Albemarle County Public Schools have faced unprecedented challenges in accomplishing its mission of establishing a community of learners and learning through relationships, relevance, and rigor, one student at a time. Our students, staff, and families have adapted to these challenges and changes with creativity, flexibility, and perseverance. Our teachers have continued to provide our students with a world-class education virtually. Our students have worked to master new skills on new learning platforms. Our families have helped to facilitate their children's virtual learning, becoming tech troubleshooters and tutors in addition to maintaining their normal day jobs. We remain grateful to them and proud of them for continuing their great work under difficult circumstances. While managing education amidst the uncertainties of a pandemic, Albemarle County Public Schools have simultaneously fought in the battle to end the predictive value of race and ensure the success of each individual student and staff member during a period of social unrest in our community and society. We have worked to eliminate the opportunity gap that exists in our division so that we can eradicate it and build a system that works for everyone in our strong and diverse community of learners. This work will help us all learn to understand difference and respect and champion the diverse life experiences of all members of our community. We are so grateful to the Virginia General Assembly for its support for public education both over the years, and doing the 2020 special session. We have seen how you make public education, a large part of the conversations that you have around legislation and funding. We know that you have made schools a priority during the pandemic crisis, and we have worked to do our part in keeping keeping our county public school community strong as we push through this unusual moment in time. A lot is being done to keep our county families strong. Our transportation and child nutrition departments have taken advantage of an FDA waiver that allows the county schools to deliver meals to our students. Every day, 7,000 meals are delivered to over 3,500 students by 62 buses. This ensures that our students have nutritious meals and an opportunity to engage with their schools. We've established a COVID-19 hotline that would allow us to provide any available resources to those in need during the pandemic. We're also expanding our mental health services, including training members of our staff in mental health first aid, so that we can help lift the emotional burden that COVID has caused in our community. Our extended day enrichment program mobilized to create a child care program for county employees, public school employees. Currently, there are more than 40 students enrolled in this program, and we are extending it as we further hope our school doors open to accommodate more of our employees. Over 1,000 hotspots have been provided to our students and employees in order to facilitate virtual learning for those who do not have reliable internet. These were provided at no cost to recipients. Our anti-racism policy steering committee has implemented a book study on Glenn Singleton's courageous conversations about race for our school board and leadership team members. This work will help us ensure that our educators can help the division eliminate the predictive value of race in our school division. Our four items in our 2021 legislative packet is aligned with all of these programs and with the work our division is doing. My colleagues will now speak on the subject of each of these four. We'll start with Mr. Alcaro, who will lead the discussion on social justice. Mr. Alcaro.

grahampaige.monologue: Thank you, Miss Collins. But this is the governor's proclamation, where school principals work cooperatively to direct, develop, and inspire all members of the school staff and student body, and to communicate effectively with parents to engage them in the learning process. And whereas principals serve as educational leaders responsible for managing the policies, regulations and procedures necessary to ensure a safe and effective learning environment for all students in Virginia's public and private schools. And whereas principals and teachers are entrusted with the opportunity and the responsibility of guiding, directing, nurturing, mentoring, and imparting knowledge to our children while they are at school. And whereas principals must work collaboratively with teachers, staff, students, parents, and the community at large to proactively prepare students to be self-reliant and productive citizens. and whereas Virginia School Principals Appreciation Week is an opportunity to recognize the hard work of Virginia schools principals and to recognize the importance of principals in ensuring that every child has access to a quality education. Now, therefore, I, Ralph S. Northam, do hereby recognize January the 8th through 14th, 2022 as Virginia School Principal Appreciation Week in our Commonwealth of Virginia. And I call this observance to the attention of all of our citizens. So we do congratulate and extend our appreciation to all of our principals. And again, we really are pleased to have at least four of our principals attending tonight.

We must continue to document and preserve the rich and brave story of African-American students in Charlottesville City and Atmau County. It is instead a joyous celebration of remarkable young men and women whose time at Burleigh comes back in pages filled with personal reflections, copies of original documents and photos, and a long list of extraordinary achievements. As a seasoned school board member, I understand the importance of crafting survey questions that effectively gauge the success of a program. To achieve accuracy, I'd propose several modifications to the existing survey questions.


Firstly, we should shift from using binary "yes/no" or Likert scale (e.g., strongly agree/agree/neither/disagree/strongly disagree) responses to open-ended or rating-scale-based answers. This change allows respondents to provide more nuanced insights into their experiences, which can help us identify specific areas for improvement.


Secondly, it's essential to eliminate leading or ambiguous language within the questions themselves. By rephrasing them in clear, concise terms, we minimize potential biases and misunderstandings among participants. For instance, instead of asking if the program has been "successful," ask what aspects have contributed most positively to student outcomes or teacher morale.


Thirdly, incorporating objective performance metrics could further enhance the assessment process. Questions might focus on quantifiable achievements such as academic achievement rates, attendance figures, or even feedback ratings from teachers and students alike.


Lastly, considering both short-term and long-term impacts is crucial when evaluating program effectiveness. Therefore, including follow-up surveys after an appropriate time interval would offer valuable insight into whether benefits endure beyond initial

The school board has adopted the procedure currently used by the Board of Supervisors in setting its member salary pursuant to Virginia Code section 15.2, 1414-3. Specifically, the school board will establish the member's salary by affirmative vote annually between May 1st and June 20th, or 30th rather. Before setting a salary each year, the board is required to hold a public hearing and provide notice as specified by Virginia Code Section 15-2, 1426 and 1427. As a school board member in Albemarle County, I can tell you that determining our salaries involves a thoughtful and transparent process. First, it's essential to note that we're elected officials, not employees of the county or school system. Our compensation is set annually through the budgeting process.

Here's how it works: each year, as part of our budget development cycle, the school division submits its proposed operating budget to the Board of Supervisors. Included within that proposal is an allocation for School Board Member compensation.

The actual amount allocated for our salaries comes from a combination of state funding guidelines and local funds. According to Virginia Code Section 22.1-32.1, school boards are entitled to receive a salary based on the average daily membership (ADM) of students enrolled in the district during the preceding academic year. This ensures that larger districts like ours have higher salaries compared to smaller ones.

When considering potential raises, we follow a deliberate approach. The Superintendent presents recommendations to the full School Board as part of the annual budget proposal. Those proposals often take into account factors such as cost-of-living adjustments, regional comparisons, and performance metrics.

Once presented, the entire Board discusses these recommendations before voting on the final budget approval. If

kateacuff.monologue: I guess I will start with this. Colleagues, I think most, you may remember that in February or February 13th, 2020 meeting, this board approved the establishment of an advisory committee on sustainability. And charged Ms. Colson and me to develop the substance of that committee. I have to confess that it fell by the wayside through much of the pandemic, but we have, Once again, met with both Rosalind Schmidt and Lindsay Snoddy on this. And we have a proposal to establish the committee, which we will, unless there's an objection, call ACES, the Advisory Committee on Environmental Sustainability. And that committee would be modeled substantially like our long-range planning committee is modeled. The mission will be largely to look at the very key areas where we can make an environmental impact in our buildings, our buses, and the education of our students and staff. It will be to coordinate with the county, which has just approved its climate action plan, And Ms. Snoddy has already reached out to Gabe Daly, who is the point person for compliance to the county's environmental plan. And he's willing to work, be a member of the committee. And we would also have a commitment to work with more broadly with regional partners such as UVA, as it turns out UVA the sustainability specialist at UVA, without prompting, reached out to me this week to talk about, to advise about a conference that I went to, webinar, on net zero schools. And so that's the whole topic. But we would propose that we work to reduce, to track or work to have our own guideposts in terms of environment sustainability. kateacuff.monologue: As we all know, Dr. Haas and his cabinet are very deeply involved in putting together the funding request that will be presented to us next week. Even at this late hour, however, I propose that Dr. Haas include in his funding request to the board a five-year overview of the capital needs of our schools. The statute that requires a superintendent to make a funding request is not specific that it's limited to operating costs, and in fact, many other school divisions include both in the funding request. And I think that we ought to be in that category, that a way to elevate our capital needs, both to the supervisors, but even more so to the community is to include the needs of our capital. You've all heard me speak with some alarm that we now have about 100 classrooms in trailers. We have a very aging infrastructure. The average age of our core school is over half a century old and they're not set up in many cases for our 21st century teaching. So I guess I propose this. I would like to have a consensus up the board and an assurance from Dr. Haas that this is feasible at this late hour.

We've heard, we said at the very beginning of our work with COVID and trying to figure out a course that we would do the best we could follow the science. The science is imperfect and continuously evolving. But I think my best judgment is we can address many of these issues by offering parents the option to send their kids to school as outlined in stage four, but seriously work on our strategy for addressing the learning losses, but the continuing work we've been doing on racism, the adverse impacts on children's education, but really put the kids first. We really owe that to our school division and the families. And I think this is an imperfect solution, but it's one that I support.

I appreciate this inquiry regarding an essential aspect of educational equity. As a dedicated school board member committed to transparency and accountability, I'll provide an objective assessment based on available data. 

According to recent reports, while we've witnessed some growth in SAT participation rates amongst economically disadvantaged students, there remains a considerable gap compared to their peers from more affluent backgrounds. The latest figures indicate that only about 45% of eligible students from low-income households took the SAT last year, which falls short of our district's goal of achieving parity.

In my view, addressing this disparity is of paramount importance for several reasons. Firstly, equal access to standardized tests like the SAT can significantly impact college admissions and scholarship opportunities. By not providing adequate support, we inadvertently perpetuate systemic barriers, thereby limiting socio-economic mobility.

Furthermore, it is our collective responsibility as educators and policymakers to ensure all students have equitable chances at success, regardless of their economic circumstances. It's imperative that we identify and implement effective strategies to bridge this gap, such as targeted outreach initiatives, free test preparation resources, and ongoing mentorship programs.

Given these concerns, I firmly believe that prioritizing increased SAT participation among economically disadvantaged students should remain a pressing concern for our school district. We must continue monitoring progress,

"Thank you for bringing up an essential topic. As a committed advocate for transparency and accountability, I believe it's crucial that we establish clear guidelines for public comment at school board meetings, particularly during these unprecedented times.

Our district has always encouraged open dialogue and valued input from the community. To ensure continued participation while prioritizing safety, we have implemented temporary adjustments to our public comment procedure amid the pandemic.

Here is how we're currently handling public comments at our virtual school board meetings:

1. **Pre-registration**: We require individuals wishing to provide public comment to pre-register via email or online form no later than 24 hours prior to the meeting. This allows us to maintain an accurate record of participants and allocate sufficient time for each speaker.

2. **Virtual queue system**: Upon registration, speakers are placed in a virtual queue, which helps us manage the order of comments efficiently.

3. **Time allocation**: Each registered speaker is allotted three minutes to share their thoughts, questions, or concerns. This timeframe may be adjusted based on the number of participants and available meeting time.

4. **Live streaming and recording**: Our virtual meetings are live-streamed and recorded, allowing those unable to participate in real-time to stay informed about discussions and decisions.

5.

Thank you for reaching out! As a committed advocate for transparency and accountability, I'm happy to provide clarity on our guidelines and procedures for public comment during virtual school board meetings.

During virtual meetings, we strive to ensure equal opportunities for public participation while maintaining an orderly and productive discussion environment. Here's how it works:

1. **Registration:** Before the meeting, individuals wishing to make a public comment must register using an online form, which includes providing their name, contact information, and a brief summary of their intended comment.

2. **Time Allocation:** Each registered speaker is allotted two minutes to address the board. This allows us to hear from multiple voices within a reasonable time frame.

3. **Virtual Queue:** Once registered speakers join the virtual meeting, they're placed in a digital waiting area until called upon by the meeting facilitator. This ensures that each commenter has an uninterrupted opportunity to speak.

4. **Respectful Dialogue:** We encourage all participants to maintain respectful tones and refrain from personal attacks or inflammatory language. Our goal is fostering open and constructive exchange, not divisive debates.

5. **Technical Support:** In case of technical issues, our support team stands ready to assist both speakers and attendees, ensuring seamless communication throughout the meeting.

6.

Thank you for bringing this topic forward. As a school board member committed to transparency and accountability, I believe it's essential to carefully consider the potential implications of any scheduling changes on all stakeholders involved, including our virtual learners.

Regarding the proposed schedule change for pre-K through third-grade students, my initial thoughts center around ensuring that we prioritize student well-being, academic success, and equity. To better understand the potential impacts, I would like to request additional information from our educational experts and administrative team.

Specifically, I'd appreciate data-driven insights into how this revised schedule might affect instructional time, teacher workload, and most importantly, student outcomes – particularly for those engaging in virtual learning environments.

It is crucial that we acknowledge the diverse needs of our student population and ensure that any adjustments made cater to both in-person and remote learners equally. By doing so, we can guarantee an environment conducive to growth, participation, and overall academic excellence.

I encourage further discussion and input from parents, educators, and students themselves to inform our decision-making process. Only through collaborative efforts and open communication can we develop a solution that truly supports every learner within our district.

Can anyone provide more insight or perspectives on this matter?"
